channel.title: NetBeans or Eclipse?
channel.description:
I'm curious guys, what do you think is more efficient, easier to navigate, easier to understand, etc. to use? NetBeans or Eclipse?
I've been mainly using Eclipse, and I like it. I'm just curious if there is limitations to Eclipse that NetBeans has? Or vise versa?
I tried downloading NetBeans, and it seemed really slow to process making new projects, etc.

item.title: NetBeans or Eclipse?
item.dc:creator: @The_AFKer The_AFKer
item.description:
@The_AFKer wrote:

TabbyKiller:

Simple and easy. Eclipse

Read full topic

item.title: NetBeans or Eclipse?
item.dc:creator: @DivineSouls DivineSouls
item.description:
@DivineSouls wrote:

Hmm, well like I said, I’m trying to figure out which program would be the best to use. Now that I know they both have some type of GUI visual development. It still seems that NetBeans has the upper hand. It is more advanced. The fact that it can tells you the CPU usage, RAM, etc.
As I’m writing this letter, I just realized I could still figure out the CPU usage, RAM on the program without NetBeans probably rather easily.

Read full topic

item.title: NetBeans or Eclipse?
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

This is like a windows v linux debate, it really just depends on the user and their attitudes.

On the bottom line, both netbeans and eclipse manage to all the basics: a source editor, syntax highlighting, display possible methods and javadocs, source formatter (indent), refactoring, debugging and some sort of gui developing. It’s just all the small things that make the differences.

I am personally a netbeans fag because I prefer the ui; everything is where you expect it to be. The class navigator is brilliant! I also find the management of projects is very easy to use; you can add, delete and modify multiple projects with your eyes closed. The workspace thing with eclipse just pisses me off.

Most people say: “netbeans is bloated 0mg0mg0mg” but I think that’s just bullshit. I will not deny that it takes a long time to load up on windows but on arch linux it loads up as fast as any other big application. For me, on arch it uses 180mb of ram and runs fine on my shit 1.6Ghz atom, 1gb netbook.

My love for netbeans is probably gained because i tried it before eclipse but I still haven’t changed mine mind. OP, you should also consider idea because I’ve heard it has many useful features but obviously you’ll have to “aquire” the full version yourself.

Read full topic

item.title: NetBeans or Eclipse?
item.dc:creator: @primadude Primadude
item.description:
@primadude wrote:

I prefer to use Eclipse, since it’s much more lightweight and faster to navigate than NetBeans. However, NetBeans is more advanced, and can give me a more in-depth description of what my java programs use in terms of hardware (RAM, CPU usage etc.); this helps me a lot when I’m trying to size down the amount of hardware needed/make my code more efficient.

Read full topic

item.title: NetBeans or Eclipse?
item.dc:creator: @Muroth Muroth
item.description:
@Muroth wrote:

[quote=“jmood128, post:6, topic:363818”][quote author=DivineSouls link=topic=460061.msg3365745#msg3365745 date=1286758557]
Hmm, I just looked at some post, it seemed as though someone was using NetBeans and was making the applet much easier then just doing it mentally. They were placing the buttons while in the program. I’m curious if Eclipse has that, because that popped out to me.

Yeah, something is going on with my computer now, 3gb ram and it’s taking 45min to download a 200mb file. Rofl, I think my computer is on a coffee break.
[/quote]

RAM has nothing to do with how fast you download a file, use speedtest.net to see your internet speed, you might need to download a higher tier to get better speeds, also good joke. :P[/quote]

And Muroth wins the race

[quote=“DivineSouls, post:7, topic:363818”]Really? So If I tried downloading a 200mb file with 256mb of ram. It would take the same amount of time?

ON TOPIC: I know what popped out at me for NetBeans, It’s the design tab. That previews on what your applet will look like, I’m curious if Eclipse has that.[/quote]
Just how fast your internet speed is/what type(:

Read full topic
